rows.title: Connect

intro_text.eng: Connecting with your child is when you focus on them and show interest in what they are doing or saying. Here’s how to get started:

step_1_text.eng:
**Make time to connect on a regular basis.**

Even 10-15 minutes can make a big difference. See it as an opportunity to take a break and relax together.

step_2_text.eng:
During one-on-one time, **give your child your full attention.** 

To help you focus on your child during one-on-one time, try to minimise distractions.

step_3_text.eng:
During one-on-one time, **be responsive and enthusiastic.**

Respond to what your child is doing and saying with enthusiasm and encouragement.

rows.title: Create

intro_text.eng: Here’s how you can create a positive environment for your child:

step_1_text.eng:
**Give positive instructions**

Positive instructions are more effective than negative instructions. Telling children what we DO want them to do works better than telling them to STOP doing something.

step_2_text.eng:
**Use praise to encourage positive behaviour**

If we praise our children when they do something well, we will see them do more and more positive things!

tips_text.eng:
Ideas for praise:
1. Being kind to someone 
2. Sharing their toys
3. Packing away their things 
4. Saying 'please' or 'thank you' 
5. Helping out around the house
6. Listening

rows.title: Play

intro_text.eng: There is no right or wrong way to play. The important thing is to have fun together. Here are some ideas for supporting your child through play:

step_1_text.eng:
**Create space and time for children to play.**

Children enjoy playing in the presence of their parents. Create space for them to play around you. Give your child praise and encouragement as they play.

step_2_text.eng:
**Join your child in their play from time to time.** 
Look for opportunities to sit down and engage in a positive way with what your child is doing. Even 10 minutes will boost your child’s development.

step_3_text.eng:
**Keep it joyful and fun!**
Being playful does not mean that your child won’t respect you or take you seriously: play actually helps to strengthen your relationship with your child. And when relationships are strong, dealing with stress and challenges become easier.

rows.title: Talk

intro_text.eng: Children learn a lot from what we say, and how we say it. Here’s how to talk to your child:

step_1_text.eng:
**Name and describe things to your child**

This helps your child understand what is happening.

step_2_text.eng:
**Explain WHY** 

This helps your child understand cause and effect. It also helps them to follow instructions.

step_3_text.eng:
**TALK with kindness** 

Use your words to build your child up, not to break them down.

rows.title: Explore solutions

intro_text.eng: Instead of solving your child’s problems for them, support them to come up with solutions that they can try themselves.

step_1_text.eng:
**Talk about the problem**
Talk to your child about the problem in need of a solution.

step_2_text.eng:
**Find solutions**
Together, think about possible solutions for this problem. What can your child do to overcome the problem?

step_3_text.eng:
**Choose a solution to try**
Let your child choose which option they want to try.

step_4_text.eng:
**Reflect and learn**
Discuss with your child whether or not the solution worked, or what they might want to do differently next time.

rows.title: Build skills

intro_text.eng: Here are some ideas for helping children build the skills they need to cope with challenges.

step_1_text.eng:
**Talk about feelings**
 Noticing and talking about feelings help children learn to express and manage their emotions – even the difficult ones.

step_2_text.eng:
**Show them how**
 Children learn a lot by watching their parents. So, instead of telling your child how to cope with a challenging situation, show them with your own behaviours.

rows.title: Care for yourself

intro_text.eng: Taking care of yourself is an important parenting skill. Let’s look at three powerful ideas.

step_1_text.eng:
**Take a pause**

Taking a pause helps us to feel calmer in stressful moments.

step_2_text.eng:
**Be kind to yourself**

Being a parent can be hard. Show yourself kindness and remind yourself of what you can be proud of.

step_3_text.eng:
**Connect with others**

Connect with your family and friends - you are not alone.

rows.title: Use books to connect

intro_text.eng: Sharing a book with your child is a great way to connect and spend quality time together.

step_1_text.eng: As you go through the book, give your child your full attention.

step_2_text.eng: Notice and respond to what your child is interested in.

step_3_text.eng: Don’t force your child if they are not interested. Rather try again another time.

rows.title: Use books to create

intro_text.eng: Here are some ideas for how you can create positive interactions during book activities:

step_1_text.eng: As you go through the book together, respond to what your child is saying in a positive and enthusiastic way.

step_2_text.eng: Avoid being critical or negative. Being critical will discourage your child from speaking or engaging in the activity.

step_3_text.eng: Praise your child’s efforts. Kindness and praise help children feel safe and confident, which helps them learn.

rows.title: Use books to play

intro_text.eng: Book activities can be playful too! Here are some ways that you can make book activities fun.

step_1_text.eng: Use a lively, playful voice, with different voices for different characters.

step_2_text.eng: You can mimic different actions from the story.

step_3_text.eng: You can also mimic different sounds from the story, like animal sounds, vehicle sounds, or nature sounds.

rows.title: Use books to care

intro_text.eng: Book activities and stories are great for taking a pause, relaxing, and having some fun with your family.

step_1_text.eng: You can use book activities to take a pause when you feel stressed.

step_2_text.eng: Connecting with others helps us feel less alone. You can use book activities to connect with your child and your family.

step_3_text.eng: Having some fun is helpful for parents too. You can use stories to relax, laugh and have fun together.

rows.title: Use books to talk

intro_text.eng: Book activities offer many opportunities for you and your child to talk and interact. Here are some ideas for how you can use books to talk and interact:

step_1_text.eng:
**Name and describe what you see in the pictures**
This helps your child learn new words and understand what is happening in the story.

step_2_text.eng:
**Ask questions**
This helps your child to talk about the pictures, and think about what is happening.

step_3_text.eng:
**Show your child you are listening.**
This will encourage your child to talk more.

rows.title: Use books to build

intro_text.eng: Here are some ideas for using books and stories to help children build their social and emotional skills:

step_1_text.eng: Talk about what the characters are feeling.

step_2_text.eng: Ask questions about what the characters are doing and why.

step_3_text.eng: Reflect together on the story and what you have learned.

rows.title: Use books to explore

intro_text.eng: Books and stories encourage children to explore different ideas and learn about the world. Here’s how to use books to explore:

step_1_text.eng:
**Ask questions about the story**
This helps children think about what is happening, why this might be happening, and what might happen next.

step_2_text.eng: Make connections between what you see in the book and your child’s life.

step_3_text.eng:
**Count and compare**  
 Use the pictures to count or make comparisons between different objects or characters.
